summary.summary: ROEB's Covid-19 response included using interim orders to establish new regulatory requirements and allowing exceptional importation of 61 drug products, which helped de-escalate 39 Tier 3 shortages between March 2020 and March 1, 2022.

chunk_text:
Appendix A: ROEB’s Covid-19 response

Interim orders (IOs)

  * ROEB used IOs to establish new regulatory requirements to prevent and mitigate therapeutic product shortages without compromising safety. These requirements have since been codified as regulations.
  * Exceptional importation: between March 2020 and March 1, 2022, 61 drug products were approved for exceptional importation. During the same period, 39 Tier 3 shortages involving exceptionally imported drugs were de-escalated

summary.summary: Health Canada took several measures to address COVID-19, including approving 313 medical devices for exceptional importation, expediting reviews of medical device and drug establishment licenses, and creating a critical drug reserve to mitigate shortages. They also worked with international partners to align regulatory approaches and maintained a centralized website for information and guidance.

chunk_text:
313 medical devices were also approved for exceptional importation.
  * Medical device shortage notification: between March 2020 and March 2024, 526 confirmed shortage reports and 8 discontinuation reports for medical devices were posted to Health Canada’s website.

Regulatory flexibilities and risk-based decision making

  * Expedited the review of medical device establishment licenses to facilitate immediate access to critical medical devices, such as PPE.
  * Expedited the review of drug establishment licenses for drugs considered important in mitigating the risks of COVID-19.
  * Enhanced flexibilities on conducting inspections and enabling some flexibility related to documentation accepted and issuing electronic licenses.

Domestic and international alignment

  * Worked with P/T health partners to share information and guidance for reprocessing N95 respirators and engaged stakeholders to mitigate and prevent drug shortages and respond to medical device shortages.
  * Maintained a centralized COVID-19 website with relevant information for industry and health professionals.
  * Worked to align policy approaches and regulatory agility across international fora, including through information-sharing and joint reviews, raising public confidence in consistent regulatory standards across the globe.

Critical drug reserve

  * Working with the P/Ts and other partners, HC established a time-limited COVID-19 critical drug reserve (CDR) in 2020 that complements other federal, provincial and territorial drug shortage management efforts, and functions as a safety net by augmenting the supply of key drugs used in treating patients with COVID-19 in Canada

summary.summary: There is no text to summarize

The ROEB transformation roadmap outlines the vision, mission, and strategic objectives of a compliance and enforcement organization. The vision is to be a world-class organization, and the mission is to protect and inform Canadians of health risks. The strategic objectives include maximizing operational efficiency, strengthening data and analytics, positioning for emerging priorities, and maintaining a strong foundation. The driving force behind this roadmap is to ensure a healthy, respectful, and inclusive workplace with the necessary tools and resources. The enablers to achieve these objectives include strengthening data and analytics, delivering digital tools, adapting automation, and improving business processes.

chunk_text:
Appendix B: ROEB transformation roadmap

Vision

  * To be a world class compliance and enforcement organization.

Mission

  * To be a compliance and enforcement leader that protects and informs Canadians of health risks associated with products, substances, and their environment.

Strategic objectives

  * Maximize operational efficiency to help drive agile, efficient, and risk-based C&E and scientific activities through process optimization activities and implementation of new tools.
  * Strengthen data and analytics to inform operational and strategic decisions through the use of data and analytics.
  * Position ROEB for emerging priorities to respond to current and emerging issues through agility in our regulatory programs and frameworks.
  * Keep foundations strong to maintain a strong base through necessary policies, tools, processes, and training geared towards efficient program delivery.

Our driving force

  * To ensure we have the workforce we need to deliver our mandate, that our employees have the tools, resources and support they need, and that our workplace is healthy, respectful, diverse, inclusive and one of choice 

Enablers

  * Strengthen data and analytics capabilities to inform decision-making.
  * Deliver digital tools and solutions to improve program efficiency by leveraging best practices.
  * Adapt and leverage automation tools to effectively manage high volume, repetitive and simple tasks to enable ROEB employees to focus on high value task and activities.
  * Use a hybrid approach to inspections (virtual/remote and on-site) across compliance and enforcement programs.
  * Adopt experimentation as a core practice to drive timely innovation.
  * Ensure regulatory oversight and coherent C&E approach to manage e-commerce and online market risks to health and safety.
  * Design and further improve efficient business processes.

summary.summary: The Canadian government launched an interim Canada dental benefit in December 2022 for children under 12 and plans to introduce the Canadian dental care plan and complementary programming for uninsured Canadians with family net incomes below $90,000, as confirmed in Budget 2023.

chunk_text:
* In December 2022, an interim Canada dental benefit (CDB) was launched, as a first step that would allow children under 12 to access dental care in the short term.
  * Budget 2023 confirmed intent to launch the Canadian dental dare plan (CDCP) and a set of complementary programming to improve the oral health of uninsured Canadians with family net incomes below $90,000

section_title: Evolution of the oral health branch

summary.summary: The Canadian government has introduced several initiatives to improve oral health access, including the Canada Dental Care Plan (CDCP) and the Oral Health Access Fund (OHAF). The CDCP began processing claims in May 2023 and is being rolled out in phases, with full implementation expected by 2025. An Oral Health Branch (OHB) was created in Fall 2023 to support the CDCP, develop the OHAF, and address barriers to accessing oral health care for certain populations.

chunk_text:
* An oral health access fund (OHAF) and some time-limited investments in oral health data were announced at the same time.
    * The CDCP opened for applications in December 2023; claims processing began in May 2023.
    * The CDCP is currently being rolled out in phases, with full implementation by 2025.
  * In Fall 2023, the oral health branch was created, bringing together the dental care task force and the office of the chief dental officer of Canada (OCDOC) from the Public Health Agency of Canada.
  * Upon its creation, the OHB was tasked with: 
    * Continuing to support the CDB, until its sunset June 30, 2024;
    * Undertaking the development and implementation of the CDCP; and
    * Designing, developing, and implementing the OHAF to help address other barriers to accessing care that would otherwise hinder the ability of certain populations to fully benefit from the CDCP or to get access to oral health care.

section_title: Office of the chief dental officer of Canada

summary.office_name: Office of the Chief Dental Officer of Canada
summary.description: The Office of the Chief Dental Officer of Canada is responsible for providing strategic leadership and direction on oral health issues in Canada. The office works to improve the oral health of Canadians by promoting evidence-based dental practices, supporting research and innovation, and developing policies and programs to address oral health disparities. The Chief Dental Officer of Canada serves as the primary advisor to the federal government on oral health matters and works collaboratively with other government agencies, dental professionals, and stakeholders to advance oral health priorities.

chunk_text: Office of the chief dental officer of Canada

keywords: Office of the Chief Dental Officer

key_partners_keywords: Office of the Chief Dental Officer of Canada
history_and_legislation_keywords: Office of the Chief Dental Officer

summary.summary: The mandate is to provide leadership and expertise in oral health, offer technical advice and consultation, and collaborate with national and international partners to address oral health challenges.

chunk_text:
Mandate

  * Provide leadership to Canadian dental practitioners and dental care professionals through the provision of expert technical and evidence-based oral health advice, consultation and information to support oral health initiatives.
  * Provide in-house clinical advice and expertise.
  * Work with partners and stakeholders nationally and internationally in identifying emerging issues, advising, facilitating, convening and building consensus
  * Act as the federal spokesperson and ambassador for oral health and lead various collaborative forums to mitigate national oral health challenges and respond to national/international cross-cutting oral health issues.

summary.summary: Represent Canada internationally on oral health, contribute expertise, and engage with various organizations, governments, and global health groups.

chunk_text:
Key files

summary.summary: The text is about funding for dental care, but there is no text to summarize.

chunk_text: Dental care funding

implementation_timeline.2023: seniors, children under 18, persons with disability

chunk_text:
Budget 2022

  * Provided “$5.3 billion over five years, starting in 2022-23, and $1.7 billion ongoing, to Health Canada to provide dental care for Canadians, starting with under 12-year-olds in 2022; followed by seniors, children under 18-year-olds, and persons with a disability in 2023; with full implementation by 2025.”

Budget 2023

Budget 2023 provided adjusted funding:

  * $13.0 billion over five years, starting in 2023-24, and $4.4 billion ongoing to implement the CDCP;
  * $250 million over three years, starting in 2025-26, and $75 million ongoing to establish the OHAF; and
  * $23.1 million over two years, starting in 2023-24, to Statistics Canada to collect data on oral health and access to dental care in Canada.
OHB profile

OHB structure

chunk_text: 8\. Digital transformation branch (DTB)

summary.summary: The Public Health Agency of Canada created the national digital transformation office in December 2020 to support the COVID-19 vaccine rollout.

chunk_text:
About us

  * In December 2020, in response to the COVID-19 pandemic, the Public Health Agency of Canada (PHAC), created the national digital transformation office (NDTO) to support the vaccine rollout

summary.summary: The information management services directorate (IMSD) team at Health Canada and the NDTO team at PHAC were merged to form a unified technology, data and digital branch under Health Canada.

chunk_text: * Recognizing the heightened importance of digital capabilities and the opportunity to harness the agility of the NDTO team, the existing information management services directorate (IMSD) team within the corporate services branch (CSB) at Health Canada and the NDTO team at PHAC were consolidated to form a single unified technology, data and digital branch under Health Canada

summary.summary: An integration was done to improve operations and deliver digital solutions, leading to the establishment of the Digital Transformation Branch (DTB) in April 2022.

chunk_text: * This integration aimed to streamline our operations and enhance our ability to deliver comprehensive and agile digital solutions. Building on these foundational elements, the digital transformation branch (DTB) was formally established in April 2022 to solidify and expand upon these core functions.

summary.summary: The digital transformation branch provides IT services to PHAC and Health Canada through a shared services partnership, consolidating functions like HR and IM/IT to ensure consistent service delivery.

chunk_text:
How we operate

  * The digital transformation branch provides enterprise IT services as a common service provider to both PHAC and Health Canada through a shared services partnership (SSP). This agreement has enabled the consolidation of several common functions, such as HR, communications, audit & evaluation and IM/IT, fostering collaboration and ensuring consistent service delivery across both organizations

summary.summary: The digital transformation branch is led by an assistant deputy minister who oversees digital transformation, cyber security, and service. The branch partners with other government agencies to deliver a range of services.

chunk_text:
* The digital transformation branch is led by an assistant deputy minister (ADM) and chief service and digital officer, who acts as the designated departmental chief information officer (CIO), the designated official for cyber security (DOCS) and the designated official for service, all of which are formal accountabilities with associated responsibilities delegated under the Treasury Board Secretariat policy suite for [service and digital](https://www.tbs-sct.canada.ca/pol/topic-sujet-eng.aspx?ta=27).
  * The digital transformation branch partners with service providers such as Shared Services Canada (SSC), Treasury Board Secretariat (TBS) and Public Services and Procurement Canada (PSPC) to deliver a wide range of services

chunk_text: Our vision and digital strategy

summary.summary: The company delivers trusted and innovative digital services.

chunk_text:
Vision

We deliver trusted innovative services in the digital age.

summary.summary: The digital strategy is built on 5 core pillars: service excellence, people and culture, robust governance, data and analytics, and enabling infrastructure. These pillars aim to drive innovation, enhance user experience, and support business growth through cutting-edge technologies and a supportive work environment.

chunk_text:
Digital strategy

Our digital strategy, built on five (5) core pillars, embraces innovation by
continually exploring and integrating cutting-edge technologies into our
rapidly evolving digital landscape.

  * Service excellence ensures that we deliver top-tier services tailored to our clients’ needs, enhancing user experience and satisfaction.
  * We prioritize people, culture and skills to foster a supportive inclusive environment that nurtures talent and promotes continuous learning.
  * Robust governance frameworks are crucial for ensuring accountability, transparency, and strategic alignment.
  * Leveraging data and analytics enables us to make informed decisions and drive innovation through insights.
  * Enabling infrastructure underpins our efforts, providing the necessary tools and technologies to support seamless, efficient operations and future growth.

Strengths and challenges

We are continuously enhancing and maturing how we run our business.

  * Stakeholder management
  * Prioritization and capacity management
  * Cost recovery and financial management
  * Governance

We view the challenges we face as opportunities for growth and improvement.

  * Funding constraints
  * Interoperability and data standards
  * Siloed IT teams
  * Competing priorities
  * Procurement and digital talent
  * Cyber security

chunk_text: 10\. Corporate services branch (CSB)

summary.summary: CSB provides internal services to Health Canada and the Public Health Agency of Canada, focusing on delivering excellent services, advice, and solutions to support their mandates, while striving for operational efficiency and a positive work environment.

chunk_text:
Mandate

CSB plays an essential role as the internal services provider for both Health
Canada (HC) and the Public Health Agency of Canada (PHAC). CSB work focuses on
excellence on the delivery of services, advice, and solutions to advance the
mandates of HC and PHAC. In an ever-changing context, CSB seeks to optimize
workforce operations and organizational effectiveness, and foster an
inclusive, psychologically healthy, accessible, bilingual, modern and safe
workplace.

summary.summary: CSB is undergoing transformation since January 2024 to adapt to post-pandemic needs, with a realignment of functions implemented on April 1, 2024, and ongoing assessment for efficiencies and effectiveness.

chunk_text:
CSB transformation

To adapt to the changing needs of HC & PHAC in a post pandemic context, CSB
has been actively transforming since January 2024. A realignment of functions
was implemented on April 1, 2024, and transformation continues through the
assessment of efficiencies, effectiveness and rationalization under the new
structure in order to support the HC and PHAC of the future.

chunk_text: 12\. Communications and public affairs branch (CPAB)

summary.summary: CPAB is a communications branch that supports Health Canada (HC) and the Public Health Agency of Canada (PHAC) in delivering their mandates, providing Canadians with access to health information.

chunk_text:
CPAB overview – what we do

  * CPAB is a full-service communications branch that directly supports HC and PHAC to deliver on their mandates through a Shared Services Partnership. This work helps to ensure that Canadians have access to the information they need to act on their health

summary.summary: CPAB provides strategic communications services, including issues management, crisis planning, media services, digital communications, and stakeholder engagement, and leads internal communications functions for HC and PHAC.

chunk_text:
* CPAB provides a broad range of strategic communications services, including issues management, crisis and risk communications planning and delivery, media services, ministerial media events, speechwriting, digital communications including web publishing and social media channel management, video and creative services, marketing and advertising, as well as services for public opinion research, consultations and stakeholder engagement. 
  * It leads internal communications functions for both HC and PHAC

summary.summary: The CPAB has three main responsibilities: leading correspondence for Health Canada (HC) and supporting the Public Health Agency of Canada (PHAC), handling reconsiderations of regulatory decisions through the Food and Drugs Act Liaison Office (FDALO), and serving as the primary liaison for communications with the Privy Council Office (PCO) and Ministers' Offices.

chunk_text:
* It leads the correspondence function for HC and supports PHAC’s correspondence work. 
  * It leads the reconsideration function for regulatory decisions through the Food and Drugs Act Liaison Office (FDALO). 
  * CPAB is the primary liaison with Privy Council Office (PCO) Communications and with Communications staff in the Ministers’ Offices for all communications issues.
program_and_operations_keywords: Food and Drugs Act Liaison Office

summary.summary: CPAB has 381 employees and a $49.7M budget, leading communications efforts for various government branches and engaging with other groups, including Legal Services, CIHR, and CFIA.

chunk_text:
CPAB overview – about us

  * CPAB has 381 full-time equivalents in the National Capital Region and across six regions and a Vote 1 budget total of $49.7M in 2024/25. Resources are derived from A-base, the Shared Services Partnership, Treasury Board Submissions, and PCO’s Central Advertising Fund. 
  * CPAB leads communications efforts for 9 HC branches, 7 PHAC branches, the Office of the CPHO, 4 SSP branches (21 direct partners) plus engages actively with Legal Services, CIHR and CFIA communications groups.

chunk_text: 13\. Office of audit and evaluation (OAE)

OAE organizational structure

The Office of Audit and Evaluation (OAE) provides independent and objective
advice and assurance to Public Health Agency of Canada (PHAC) and Health
Canada (HC) senior management on the adequacy and effectiveness of risk
management, controls, and governance, as well as the relevance and performance
of programs.

Chief Audit and Evaluation Executive  
Shelley Borys

Program Evaluation and Internal Disclosure  
Amanda Hayne-Farrell, Executive Director

Internal Audit and Special Examinations  
Pascal Robert, A/Executive Director

Practice Management  
Blenda Jong, A/Director

summary.summary: There is no text to summarize.

chunk_text: Our divisions

summary.summary: Internal auditing provides independent assurance that an organization's processes and controls are operating correctly, while special examinations investigate allegations of fraud or financial loss.

chunk_text:
Internal audit and special examinations

Internal auditing provides independent, risk-based assurance that an
organization’s governance processes, risk management, and internal controls
are operating as intended by senior management and will help the organization
achieve its objectives. ​We also provide special examination services for
allegations of fraud or loss of money.

summary.summary: The program involves evaluating performance and improvements through evidence collection and analysis, and also includes a secure process for reporting serious workplace wrongdoing.

chunk_text:
Program evaluation and internal disclosure

Evaluations involve the collection and analysis of evidence to assess the
performance of programs, initiatives and policies in a systematic and neutral
way, as well as provide considerations for how programs can be improved. We
also ensure a secure and confidential process for disclosing serious
wrongdoing in the workplace.

summary.summary: The practice management team oversees quality assurance, audits, evaluation planning, and governance, and coordinates with external providers to implement action plans based on recommendations

chunk_text:
Practice management

The practice management team is responsible for quality assurance, annual
audit and evaluation planning, governance of audit and evaluation committees,
liaising and coordinating with external assurance providers, and following up
on action plans to respond to recommendations.

summary.summary: No text provided to summarize how work is done for an audit

chunk_text: How we do our work (audit)

summary.summary: Conduct risk-based audit planning by identifying key risks, developing a plan aligned with internal audit standards, consulting with senior management, and obtaining departmental audit committee recommendation for approval.

chunk_text:
Conduct risk-based audit planning

  * Identify key risks and timing for departmental audit and advisory projects over a two-year cycle.
  * Development of plan (aligned with TB’s policy on internal audit and institute of internal auditor’s global internal audit standards).
  * Consultation with senior management within each branch.
  * Departmental audit committee (DAC) recommendation for DM approval of final plan.

summary.summary: Conduct audit and advisory engagements in three steps: 1) share terms of reference with the office of primary interest (OPI), 2) present preliminary findings to OPI for fact validation, and 3) undergo a rigorous internal quality assurance process for all draft reports

chunk_text:
Conduct audit and advisory engagements

  * Terms of reference are shared with the office of primary interest (OPI).
  * Preliminary findings are presented to OPI for fact validation.
  * All draft reports go through a rigorous internal quality assurance process.

summary.summary: The final audit reports and management response/action plan are reviewed by the executive committee and DAC, then submitted to DM for approval.

chunk_text:
Report results off engagements

  * Final audit reports and the management response and action plan (MRAP) are presented to executive committee and DAC for review and feedback.
  * Report is submitted to DM for approval.

summary.summary: Audit reports are published on a Health Canada website within 90 business days of approval and also sent to TBS

chunk_text:
Publish audit reports

  * Audit reports are published on a dedicated Health Canada website within 90 business days of DM approval.
  * Audit reports are sent to TBS after DM approval.

section_title: Follow-up on management response and action plans

summary.summary: A follow-up process is in place to ensure management deliverables are on track, with the DM receiving a bi-annual update on MRAP progress

chunk_text:
Follow-up on management response and action plans

  * Follow up process to ensure deliverables are proceeding as planned.
  * Every six months, the DM receives a docket updating on MRAP progress.

summary.summary: The evaluation process involves four stages: planning, conducting evaluations, reporting results, and publishing reports. Planning includes determining requirements and consulting with programs and central agencies. Conducting evaluations involves developing a scope and presenting preliminary findings. Reporting results involves presenting final reports and management responses to the Performance Measurement Evaluation and Results Committee (PMERC) and the Deputy Minister (DM) for approval. Finally, publishing reports involves submitting them to the Treasury Board Secretariat (TBS) within 14 days of DM approval.

chunk_text:
How we do our work (evaluation)

**Conduct evaluation planning**

  * Determination of requirements (FAA and TB Submissions).
  * Consultation with programs and central agencies.
  * Confirmation with the performance measurement evaluation and results committee (PMERC) and DM approval of plan.

**Conduct evaluations**

  * Develop scope of evaluation (activities covered and questions asked) with programs and present to PMERC for endorsement.
  * Present preliminary findings to PMERC for endorsement or gap identification.

**Report evaluation results**

  * Final reports are presented to PMERC for endorsement.
  * The program is responsible to present the management response and action plan (MRAP).
  * Report is submitted to DM for approval.

**Publish evaluation reports**

  * Reports are sent to TBS within 14 days of DM approval

keywords: performance measurement evaluation and results committee

summary.summary: Reports are published within 120 days on a Health Canada website. A follow-up process ensures management deliverables are on track, with progress updates every 6 months and revisions based on PMERC feedback.

chunk_text:
* Reports are published on a dedicated Health Canada website within 120 days.

**Follow up on management response and action plans**

  * Follow up process to ensure deliverables are proceeding as planned.
  * Every six months, the DM receives a docket updating on MRAP progress.

Revise as needed based on PMERC feedback.

summary.summary: Oversight work is guided by principles, including collaboration with program areas during all stages of engagement.

chunk_text:
Fundamental principles

Regardless of the oversight function, there are several principles that guide
our work.

  * Collaboration - we work closely with program areas during all stages of engagement – from the development of questions and criteria in scoping to the formulation of recommendations in the final report

This ensures no surprises at all points in the process.
  * Verification - over the years, we have built in several steps in our process of verifying the accuracy of findings, as well as the feasibility of recommendations.  This includes work with the programs as well as governance check-ins. 
  * Evidence-based approach - through the use of sound and rigorous methods during engagements, we provide findings that are accurate and appropriate for the current context of a program.

summary.summary: Recently completed audit engagements include internal audits with approved management responses and action plans, which are tracked and reported on semi-annually. Consultancy services were also provided, with key findings available in the annex.

chunk_text:
Recently completed audit engagements

The following internal audits include an approved management response and
action plan (MRAP) to respond to the areas identified for improvement. These
MRAPs are followed up semi-annually by OAE who assesses, tracks, and reports
on the completion of the MRAPs. We also provided consultancy services. Key
findings can be found in the annex.

chunk_text: Departmental audit committee

summary.summary: The Departmental Audit Committee (DAC) is an advisory body that provides guidance to the deputy head on internal audit engagements and reviews management processes using a risk-based approach.

chunk_text:
About the departmental audit committee (DAC)

The DAC, under the Policy on Internal Audit,  is an advisory body which
provides advice and recommendations to the deputy head on sufficiency, quality
and results of internal audit engagements, and on matters as requested by the
deputy head.

  * Reviews management, control, and accountability processes using a risk-based approach.

summary.summary: DAC's areas of responsibility include values and ethics, risk management, management control, internal audit, external assurance, follow-up on management action plans, and financial reporting.

chunk_text:
DAC’s areas of responsibility

Values and ethics, risk management, management control framework, internal
audit function, external assurance providers, follow-up on management action
plans, financial and accountability reporting.

DAC membership

External members – Leah Collins, Lorraine Maheu, Linda Lizotte-MacPerson, and
Aslam Bhatti. Internal members – deputy minister, associate deputy minister,
chief financial officer, and chief audit and evaluation executive.

2024-25 meetings

Remaining 2024-25 DAC meetings are scheduled as follows:

  * October 9-10, 2024
  * December 17-18, 2024
  * February 25, 2025

section_title: Performance measurement, evaluation and results committee

summary.summary: The Performance Measurement, Evaluation and Results Committee is a group responsible for assessing and evaluating the performance of an organization, program, or project, with the goal of achieving desired outcomes and objectives.

section_title: About the performance measurement, evaluation and results committee

summary.summary: The Performance Measurement, Evaluation and Results Committee (PMERC) is a committee comprised of Executive Committee (EC) members that meets four times a year to discuss evaluation topics. Each evaluation is discussed in three stages: scoping, preliminary findings, and final report with management response and action plan.

chunk_text:
About the performance measurement, evaluation and results committee
(PMERC)

  * The performance measurement, evaluation and results committee (PMERC) is comprised of executive committee (EC) members and meets four times a year on evaluation topics (the head of performance measurement schedules other PMERC meetings that focus on performance measurement).
  * Each evaluation is discussed at three stages: scoping; preliminary findings; and final report and management response and action plan (MRAP).

2024-25 meetings

Remaining 2024-25 PMERC Meetings are scheduled as follows:

  * October 3, 2024
  * January 23, 2025
  * March 20, 2025

section_title: Key findings from recently completed audits

summary.summary: A recent audit of drug shortage reporting in Canada found that the governance framework effectively supports oversight and management of drug shortages, with identified strategic and operational risks being managed.

chunk_text:
Key findings from recently completed audits

1\. Audit of drug shortage reporting, monitoring, and compliance activities

  * Timing – May 2024
  * Program profile - HC’s drug shortages response management
  * Key findings - overall, it was found that the governance framework supports the oversight and management of drug shortages in Canada. There is an awareness of strategic and operational risks that are being identified and managed

section_title: Key findings from recently completed audits

summary.summary: There are opportunities to strengthen risk management, internal processes, and compliance monitoring to prevent and manage drug shortages and support mandatory reporting by manufacturers.

chunk_text:
At the same time, there are opportunities to formalize and strengthen strategic and operational risk management and the internal processes and controls in place to prevent and manage shortages, as well as to strengthen and formalize compliance monitoring to support mandatory drug shortage reporting by manufacturers.

2\

section_title: Key findings from recently completed audits

summary.summary: An audit of cyber security at Health Canada (HC) and the Public Health Agency of Canada (PHAC) found that while they have implemented some governance and risk management processes to mitigate cyber security risks, there are opportunities for further improvement.
key_points: Program profile: IT security governance and risk management
Key findings: Opportunities for improvement in governance and risk management processes

chunk_text:
Audit of cyber security at HC and PHAC

  * Timing - November 2023
  * Program profile - IT security governance and risk management processes designed to counter and mitigate cyber security risks
  * Key findings - overall, HC and PHAC implemented elements of the governance and risk management processes needed to identify and mitigate cyber security risks. However, the audit identified opportunities to further improve the key governance and risk management processes at HC and PHAC.

3\

However, we found that there are opportunities for the Department to improve risk management at the branch level by formalizing and standardizing related practices.

section_title: Key findings from recently completed audits

summary.summary: Management can improve risk management practices by enhancing collaboration and communication among stakeholders and clarifying risk assessment approaches. An audit readiness assessment for COVID-19 rapid testing found that Health Canada and the Public Health Agency of Canada established adequate governance, risk management, and controls for the rapid testing initiative.

chunk_text:
However, management could strengthen risk management practices by improving risk-related collaboration and communication between all stakeholders within PMRA and clarifying the approach for assessing risks.

However, the two organizations experienced some communication challenges with respect to procurement and contract amendments. In addition, improvements could be made in the collection and analysis of sufficient data to allow them to measure the success of the initiative against its overall objective of helping to curb COVID-19 transmission.

section_title: Key findings from recently completed evaluations

summary.summary: PCHOs have made progress in enhancing health system capacity and supporting improvements, but opportunities for improvement include increasing communication, re-examining governance mechanisms, and prioritizing requests.

chunk_text:
​
    * PCHOs made progress towards enhancing health system capacity, changing the behaviour of healthcare decision makers, and supporting improvements in health systems.​
    * Opportunities for improvement include increasing communication from the health portfolio, re-examining existing governance mechanisms and prioritizing requests to PCHOs.

section_title: Key findings from recently completed evaluations

summary.summary: The regulation of pharmaceutical drugs in Canada has seen increased complexity and submission volume, leading to longer pre-market review times. Modernization efforts have been made since 2017, but the post-pandemic period offers a chance to reassess priorities.

chunk_text:
Pharmaceutical drugs

  * Program profile - Regulation of human and veterinary pharmaceutical drugs sold in Canada.
  * Key findings 
    * Due to the number and complexity of submissions, pre-market reviews required more time than before. Decisions for generic drugs have been made increasingly closer to the deadlines. 
    * Several changes were put in place since 2017 to modernize regulatory processes. However, the end of the pandemic provides an opportunity to review priorities.

4\

section_title: Key findings from recently completed evaluations

summary.summary: The Chemicals Management Plan (CMP) is a joint initiative with Environment and Climate Change Canada aimed at reducing the risks posed by chemical substances. Key findings indicate that the CMP's activities have successfully reduced human and environmental exposures, but the program's work is becoming increasingly complex due to evolving expectations and a changing landscape.

chunk_text:
Chemicals management plan

  * Program profile - joint initiative with Environment and Climate Change Canada aimed at reducing the risks posed by chemical substances to Canadians and the environment.
  * Key findings 
    * CMP’s risk management activities, compliance promotion and enforcement actions have served to reduce human and environmental exposures.
    * The evolving Canadian chemicals management landscape and expectations of increased transparency make CMP’s work increasingly complex

section_title: Key findings from recently completed evaluations

summary.summary: The Canadian Medical Plan (CMP) needs to reassess its priorities. The Territorial Health Investment Fund (THIF) provides grants to 3 territories for healthcare services and sustainable systems. Key findings show THIF enabled territories to offer direct healthcare, recruit/train staff, and adopt new technologies.

chunk_text:
CMP will need to review its priorities to better meet future needs and expectations.

5\. Territorial health investment fund

  * Program profile - grants to the 3 territories to support access to health service and territorial initiatives to build sustainable health care systems.
  * Key findings 
    * THIF allowed territories to offer direct health care services, recruit and train staff and adopt new technologies to improve service delivery

section_title: Key findings from recently completed evaluations

summary.summary: The initiative has enabled each territory to improve Indigenous health and includes a Canadian drugs and substances strategy, which provides a comprehensive approach to drug policy.

chunk_text:
It has also enabled each territory to plan and execute initiatives to improve Indigenous health on multiple fronts.

6\. Canadian drugs and substances strategy

  * Program profile - Joint pan-governmental initiative providing a comprehensive, collaborative, compassionate and evidence-based approach to drug policy

keywords: Canadian drugs and substances strategy partners

section_title: Key findings from recently completed evaluations

summary.summary: The report addresses various substances, including cannabis, alcohol, and opioids, highlighting their impact as a public health issue. Key findings include the expansion of harm reduction and treatment services, but also note the need for further work in prevention and addressing root causes related to social determinants of health.

chunk_text:
It covers a range of legal and illegal substances, including cannabis, alcohol, and opioids.
  * Key findings 
    * It helped to frame substance use as a public health issue and contributed to expanding access to harm reduction and treatment services. 
    * More work is needed in prevention and in better addressing the root causes of substance use, including the relationship with social determinants of health

section_title: Key findings from recently completed evaluations

summary.summary: There are gaps in addressing alcohol use and limited data on measuring the impact of strategies to address drug and substance use as a health and social issue.

chunk_text:
Addressing alcohol use is a gap in the current approach.
    * There remain gaps in disaggregated surveillance data, as well as limited information to effectively measure the strategy’s impact to address drug and substance use as a health and social issue.

7\

section_title: 14\. Office of international affairs (OIA) for the health portfolio

summary.summary: The Office of International Affairs (OIA) is responsible for managing international relations and collaborations within the health portfolio.

chunk_text: 14\. Office of international affairs (OIA) for the health portfolio

summary.summary: The Office of International Affairs (OIA) supports Canada's domestic and foreign health policy objectives by advancing international health priorities and promoting Canada's interests and values globally.

chunk_text:
Mandate

OIA strategically advances the health portfolio’s international priorities in
support of Canada's domestic health policy and foreign policy objectives and
ensures that Canada's interests and values are reflected in the global health
agenda.

summary.summary: OIA's key function is to lead global health governance and engage in international relations, both multilaterally and bilaterally.

chunk_text:
OIA key functions

International relations and engagement

  * Lead global health governance for the health portfolio; engage multilaterally and bilaterally

summary.summary: The text describes two main tasks: (1) building and sustaining relationships and networks to support international events and exchanges, and (2) providing global health policy coherence and international cooperation to advance health priorities. This includes providing advice and support for international events, sharing information, and collaborating on global health issues.

chunk_text:
Build and sustain relationships and networks, establish and advance collaborative strategies.
  * Provide protocol and logistics advice and support for international events and official visits to support international exchanges, whether incoming visits or outbound missions.

Global health policy coherence

  * Provide horizontal global health policy coherence and international cooperation to advance the ministerial mandate and health portfolio global health priorities.
  * Share information, collaborate, and provide strategic advice on global health issues

summary.summary: The Office of International Affairs (OIA) collaborates with other health organizations and government departments to address global health issues and serves as a central point of contact for international health affairs, reporting to Health Canada and the Public Health Agency of Canada (PHAC) Deputy Heads.

chunk_text:
Liaise with other health portfolio partners (CFIA, CIHR, PMPRB) and other government departments (e.g. GAC)] to foster a concerted approach to global health issues.

OIA is situated in PHAC and reports to both Health Canada and PHAC Deputy
Heads. It is the single window into the international affairs of the health
portfolio for the minister, the Deputies, other departments and international
partners.

Multilateral relations division

Bilateral Engagement Summits & Trade  
Ranu Sharma, A/Director

Plus two health counsellors in Geneva and Washington, reporting to the
director general.  
Chief negotiator for pandemic instrument, Zoe Kahn, reports to PHAC & HC
deputies.

section_title: Mega trends impacting public health globally, including Canada

summary.summary: No text provided to summarize.

section_title: Mega trends impacting public health globally, including Canada

summary.summary: There are 7 mega trends impacting public health globally, including Canada: climate crisis, non-communicable diseases and mental health, health care equity, healthcare workforce, demographic shifts, digitalized futures, and health emergency prevention/preparedness/response. These trends encompass various aspects of public health, including environmental factors, disease prevention, healthcare access, workforce sustainability, population changes, technology integration, and emergency preparedness.

chunk_text:
Mega trends impacting public health globally, including Canada

  * Climate crisis - heat related illness and death, migrant health, food and water-borne contamination, vector-borne diseases, droughts and wildfire, precipitation changes.
  * Non-communicable diseases and mental health - chronic disease prevention and management, mental health, substance use.
  * Health care equity - access to health products and services, increasing cost of living, malnutrition, water and sanitation, child and maternal care, mental health, gender equality, social/economic/environmental determinants of health.
  * Healthcare workforce - healthcare worker shortage, health system sustainability.
  * Demographic shifts - aging population, urbanisation, migration.
  * Digitalized futures - telemedicine, personalized care, artificial intelligence and machine learning, data privacy.
  * Health emergency prevention/preparedness/response - infectious disease prevention, routine immunization, drug resistance, data quality and availability

chunk_text: B. Legislative and regulatory responsibilities

summary.summary: In Canada, health is a shared jurisdiction between provinces and the federal government, with provinces responsible for hospitals, local matters, property, and civil rights under the Constitution Act, 1867

chunk_text:
Introduction

In Canada, health is an area of shared jurisdiction. Under the _Constitution
Act_ , 1867, provincial responsibilities include the establishment,
maintenance and management of hospitals, local matters, and property and civil
rights

summary.summary: In Canada, provinces and territories are responsible for healthcare delivery, insurance administration, and health profession regulation, while the federal government has authority over health matters through its powers related to criminal law, taxation, and spending.

chunk_text:
Over time, courts have interpreted these constitutional provisions to
mean that provinces and territories (PTs) are primarily responsible for health
care delivery, the administration of provincial health insurance plans, and
the regulation of health professions.

Federal authorities in health are grounded in the federal government’s
constitutional responsibilities for criminal law and taxation, and the federal
spending power

summary.summary: The described responsibilities focus on protecting Canadians' health and safety by regulating various products and services, while Parliament has the authority to manage taxation and spending with attached terms and conditions.

chunk_text:
These responsibilities provide the basis for helping to
protect the health and safety of Canadians through the regulation of drugs,
food, medical devices, controlled substances, cannabis, tobacco and vaping
products, consumer products and cosmetics, pest control products, and medical
assistance in dying.

Parliament also has the authority to spend money raised through taxation, and
to attach terms and conditions to the authorized spending
program_and_operations_keywords: regulation of tobacco and vaping products

summary.summary: The Canada Health Act sets criteria for provincial health insurance plans to receive full funding, and the federal government has a role in national health emergencies and public health matters of national concern.

chunk_text:
Accordingly, the
_Canada Health Act_ establishes the criteria and conditions PT health
insurance plans must meet to receive their full cash entitlement under the
Canada health transfer.

Rooted in the “peace, order and good government” provisions of the
constitution, the federal government also has key functions in relation to
national health emergencies, and where public health matters are issues of
national concern

summary.summary: Federal power in public health has expanded since the 1970s to include health research, promotion, disease prevention, and health information, and is not limited to the health portfolio.

chunk_text:
Since the 1970s, federal power in public health has been
interpreted to also include efforts in health research and promotion, disease
prevention and health information.

Several other federal responsibilities include health elements, not all of
which fall within the purview of the health portfolio

summary.summary: Economic powers include trade, commerce, patents, and responsibilities in foreign affairs, immigration, and health services for specific populations such as First Nations, Inuit, refugees, and the military.

chunk_text:
This includes economic
powers related to trade; commerce and patents, which apply to drugs; medical
devices and technologies; responsibilities in foreign affairs and immigration
that relate to migration health (e.g., admission of foreign nationals with
international credentials, and relations with international bodies and foreign
governments); and supplementary benefits and health services for certain
populations (First Nations and Inuit, refugees, the military).

summary.summary: The government uses various legislative mechanisms, including acts, regulations, and orders in council, to achieve its objectives in the health portfolio, with acts being laws enacted by parliament and regulations having legally binding effects.

chunk_text:
Health portfolio legislation and regulation

There is a range of legislative mechanisms that the government can use to meet
its desired objectives. Legislative tools include acts (statutes),
regulations, and orders in council, all of which are relevant in the health
portfolio context. While acts are laws enacted by parliament, regulations also
have legally binding effects

summary.summary: In Canada, the power to make regulations is typically given by parliament to the governor in council, a minister, or an agency. The Minister of Health is responsible for administering and enforcing around 40 acts and their regulations that impact Canadian health and safety, including three key enabling statutes that govern the activities of Health Canada, the Public Health Agency of Canada, and the Canadian Food Inspection Agency.

chunk_text:
Normally, the power to make regulations is
conferred by parliament to the governor in council (cabinet), a minister, or,
occasionally, an agency.

The Minister of Health is responsible for the administration and enforcement
of aspects of approximately 40 acts (and their associated regulations) that
have a direct impact on the health and safety of Canadians.

Three of the acts are enabling statutes, for which the minister is responsible
for; that is, they create and provide the basis of the activities of the three
largest portfolio organizations – Health Canada, the Public Health Agency of
Canada, and the Canadian Food Inspection Agency.

These acts set out specific responsibilities carried out by these
organizations in relation to the minister’s statutory responsibilities

summary.summary: The Canadian government has laws and agencies in place to promote the well-being of Canadians, including the Department of Health Act, Public Health Agency of Canada Act, and Canadian Food Inspection Agency Act, which focus on physical, social, and mental health, public health measures, and food safety.

chunk_text:
These
include:  the promotion of the physical, social, and mental well-being of
Canadians (_Department of Health Act_); taking public health measures,
identifying and reducing public health risk factors, and supporting national
readiness for public health threats (_Public Health Agency of Canada Act_);
and setting safety standards for food sold in Canada, as well as enforcing the

summary.summary: The Patent Act establishes the Patented Medicine Prices Review Board, and the Canadian Institutes of Health Research Act created the Canadian Institutes of Health Research (CIHR) in 2000, an agency that reports to parliament via the Minister of Health

chunk_text:
In
addition, the _Patent Act_ provides the legislative basis for the
establishment and functioning of the Patented Medicine Prices Review Board. As
well, the _Canadian Institutes of Health Research Act_ created in 2000 the
Canadian Institutes of Health Research (CIHR), an arm’s-length agency that is
under the management responsibility of its governing council and that reports
to parliament via the Minister of Health

summary.summary: The Canadian Institutes of Health Research (CIHR) aims to create new knowledge and improve Canadian health through effective services and products, while the Minister is responsible for administering the Canada Health Act.

chunk_text:
The objective of the CIHR is to
excel in the creation of new knowledge and its translation into improved
health for Canadians, more effective health services and products and a
strengthened Canadian health care system.

The Minister also has important responsibilities in relation to the
administration of the _Canada Health Act_ (CHA), Canada’s federal legislation
on insured health services

summary.summary: The Canada Health Act (CHA) sets national principles for the Canadian healthcare system, ensuring access to health services without financial barriers. The Public Health Agency of Canada Act mandates the agency to assist the Minister of Health in public health matters, including emergency preparedness and response.

chunk_text:
The CHA defines the national principles that
govern the Canadian health care system and aims to “… protect, promote and
restore the physical and mental well-being of residents of Canada and to
facilitate reasonable access to health services without financial or other
barriers.” It establishes the criteria and conditions provincial and
territorial health insurance plans must meet to receive their full cash
entitlements under the Canada health transfer.

The _Public Health Agency of Canada Act_ mandates the Public Health Agency of
Canada and the Chief Public Health Officer to assist the Minister of Health
"in exercising or performing the minister's powers, duties and functions of
public health", which includes public health emergency preparedness and
response

Under the _Emergency Management Act_ , the Minister of Health has
specific responsibilities to identify risks pertinent to his or her mandate
and develop plans to address these risks. The Chief Public Health Officer also

summary.summary: Canada's health portfolio has emergency plans for public health risks like pandemic influenza and foodborne illness, and the Quarantine Act gives the Minister power to take measures to prevent the spread of communicable diseases.

Emergency plans
have been developed by the health portfolio that address a variety of public
health risks (for example, pandemic influenza and foodborne illness).

To prevent the introduction and spread of communicable diseases in Canada, the
_Quarantine Act_ gives the Minister (and other designated officials) the power
to take comprehensive public health measures

_Quarantine Act_ also provides the governor in council the authority to issue

Under the _Food and Drugs Act_ and the _Pest Control Products Act_ , the
minister also has the authority to issue interim orders (IO) if immediate

In addition to enabling statutes, there are several statutes that assign the

summary.summary: The Minister of Health has specific responsibilities under various federal statutes and strategies, including regulating food, drugs, substances, and products, as well as addressing health issues like palliative care, Lyme disease, and dementia.

chunk_text:
There are
assigned statutes that establish federal frameworks (e.g., palliative care,
lyme disease, post-traumatic stress disorder) or national strategies (e.g.,
dementia), which confer specific responsibilities on the Minister of Health.

The balance of the assigned statutes relevant to the health portfolio set out
responsibilities to be carried out by the Minister of Health in the context of
regulating food, pharmaceutical drugs, controlled substances, tobacco and
vaping products, pest control products, medical devices, biologics, human
toxins and pathogens, radiation-emitting devices, and consumer products and
cosmetics.

There are significant differences in the nature of these various regulatory
regimes

summary.summary: The text discusses common principles of decision-making related to the Minister of Health's role.

chunk_text:
However, some principles of decision-making are common to many of the
acts for which the Minister of Health is identified as exercising a role. The
following section sets out some key principles.

section_title: Powers, duties and functions in legislation

summary.summary: Legislation assigns powers, duties, and functions to individual ministers, who are either named in the act or designated by the governor in council.

chunk_text:
Powers, duties and functions in legislation

Most acts of parliament and associated regulations are administered by
individual ministers, and this responsibility can include a variety of powers,
duties, and functions. Depending on the legislation (or regulations), the
responsible minister can be named in the act itself or designated by the
governor in council (i.e. cabinet).

Typically, the various powers, duties and functions set out in an act or
regulations are assigned to the responsible minister

section_title: Powers, duties and functions in legislation

summary.summary: Specific authorities can be assigned to other individuals or groups in certain circumstances

chunk_text:
However, in some
circumstances, specific authorities are assigned to other identified
individuals or groups of individuals

section_title: Powers, duties and functions in legislation

summary.summary: The Minister of Health sets policy direction and develops regulations, while the governor in council has power to make regulations and amend schedules. The Minister is responsible for managing the Department of Health and can delegate powers to the Deputy Minister.

chunk_text:
For example, powers to make regulations
and amend schedules to an act are often assigned to the governor in council.
In all cases, the Minister of Health would still be involved in setting
overall policy direction for regulatory programs, developing regulations, and
approving regulations recommended to the governor in council.

The _Department of Health Act_ provides that the minister “has the management
and direction of the department” and must “coordinate the activities of, and
establish strategic priorities for, any board or agency for which the minister
is responsible and may, subject to any terms and conditions that the minister
considers appropriate, delegate those powers, duties and functions to the
Deputy Minister of Health”.

section_title: A. Powers, duties and functions of the Deputy Minister of Health

summary.summary: The Deputy Minister of Health is appointed by the governor in council and serves at pleasure, acting under the Minister's direction and responsible for departmental management and control.

chunk_text:
A. Powers, duties and functions of the Deputy Minister of Health

The Deputy Minister of Health is appointed by the governor in council on the
Prime Minister’s recommendation and holds office during pleasure, pursuant to
s. 3 of the _Department of Health Act_. The deputy minister acts generally
under the direction of the minister, who maintains responsibility for the
overall management and control of the department of health

section_title: A. Powers, duties and functions of the Deputy Minister of Health

summary.summary: The powers, duties, and functions of the deputy minister come from 4 main sources of law.

chunk_text:
The powers, duties
and functions of the deputy minister are derived from four main sources of
law:

1\

section_title: A. Powers, duties and functions of the Deputy Minister of Health

summary.summary: The deputy minister has the power to act on behalf of the minister due to Section 24 of the Interpretation Act, which includes the deputy minister and other department staff in legislation directing or empowering a minister.

chunk_text:
The general and implicit power to act on behalf of the minister

The deputy minister is empowered to act on behalf of the minister as section
24 of the _Interpretation Act_ provides that words in legislation directing or
empowering a minister of the crown to do an act or thing applying to that
minister as the holder of the office, include the deputy minister and persons
appointed to serve in the department with appropriate capacity

section_title: A. Powers, duties and functions of the Deputy Minister of Health

summary.summary: A minister is not required to personally exercise all statutory powers and can be assisted by departmental officials. The minister can also delegate powers and responsibilities to the deputy minister through legislation.

chunk_text:
This authority
recognizes that a minister is not required to exercise all of statutory powers
personally but is assisted by departmental officials for that purpose.

2\. Powers delegated by the minister to the deputy head through legislation

Many powers and responsibilities are delegated to the deputy minister by the
minister through specific provisions in various pieces of legislation

section_title: A. Powers, duties and functions of the Deputy Minister of Health

summary.summary: The Financial Administration Act and other legislation, such as the Privacy Act and Access to Information Act, outline the minister's responsibility to authorize and delegate powers to certain individuals or positions within a department, including the deputy head.

chunk_text:
For
instance, section 34 of the _Financial Administration Act_ requires that the
minister authorize the person or positions who are responsible for the
payment, certification and verification of financial expenditures in the
department. Other legislation such as the _Privacy Act_ (section 71) or the
_Access to Information Act_ (section 73) provides that the minister may
delegate its powers to the deputy head.  

3\

section_title: A. Powers, duties and functions of the Deputy Minister of Health

summary.summary: The deputy minister of health has specific powers and responsibilities under legislation, including commitment control, maintaining records, and ensuring internal audit capacity, as outlined in the Financial Administration Act.

chunk_text:
Powers directly vested in deputy heads by legislation

As a deputy head, the deputy minister of health has some specific powers and
responsibilities stemming directly from legislation. For instance, the
_Financial Administration Act_ imposes on the deputy head the specific
obligations for commitment control (section 32), maintaining adequate records
in relation to public property (section 62) or ensuring appropriate internal
audit capacity (section 16.1)

section_title: A. Powers, duties and functions of the Deputy Minister of Health

summary.summary: A deputy head has various powers and responsibilities in human resources management under several acts, including the Financial Administration Act, the Federal Public Sector Labour Relations Act, and the Public Service Employment Act.

chunk_text:
A deputy head also has numerous direct powers
and responsibilities in human resources management stemming from the
_Financial Administration Act_ , the _Federal Public Sector Labour Relations
Act_ and the _Public Service Employment Act_

section_title: A. Powers, duties and functions of the Deputy Minister of Health

summary.summary: The deputy minister has authority to penalize, suspend, demote, or terminate employees for disciplinary or non-disciplinary reasons, including unsatisfactory performance, under subsection 12(1) of the Financial Administration Act.

chunk_text:
For instance, the deputy
minister has the authority under subsection 12(1) of the _Financial
Administration Act_ to financially penalize, suspend, demote or terminate any
employee for disciplinary reasons and to terminate or demote employees for
non-disciplinary reasons, including unsatisfactory performance

section_title: A. Powers, duties and functions of the Deputy Minister of Health

summary.summary: The deputy minister has authority under the Public Service Employment Act to determine qualifications, deploy employees, lay off employees, and terminate employment of probationary employees.

chunk_text:
The deputy
minister has direct authority under the _Public Service Employment Act_ to
determine qualifications for positions to be staffed (section 31), to deploy
employees (section 51), to lay off (subsection 64(1)), or to terminate the
employment of employees on probation (section 62)

section_title: A. Powers, duties and functions of the Deputy Minister of Health

summary.summary: The deputy minister has authority to establish a consultation committee, create a code of conduct, and designate a senior officer to handle wrongdoing complaints under various acts, including the Federal Public Sector Labour Relations Act and the Public Servants Disclosure Protection Act.

chunk_text:
The deputy minister has
direct authority under the _Federal Public Sector Labour Relations Act_ to
establish a consultation committee (article 8), in consultation with the
bargaining agents, under the _Public Servants Disclosure Protection Act_ , the
deputy minister is responsible for establishing a code of conduct applicable
to the department of health, establishing internal procedures to manage
disclosures made under this act, and designating a senior officer to be
responsible for receiving and dealing with complaints of wrongdoing.

Finally, the deputy head has the authority in legislation to receive notices
and reports from tribunals and other investigative bodies, including the
Canadian International Trade Tribunal, the Commissioner of Official Languages,
or the Canadian Security Intelligence Service.

section_title: A. Powers, duties and functions of the Deputy Minister of Health

summary.summary: The deputy minister of the Department of Health has been delegated certain powers, including the authority to appoint under the Public Service Employment Act and to make ex gratia payments, as authorized by Treasury Board.

chunk_text:
Powers delegated to the deputy minister by others

The authority to appoint under the _Public Service Employment Act_ belongs to
the Public Service Commission, but has been delegated to the deputy minister
for positions within the department of health (section 15 of the _Public
Service Employment Act_).  Order in council (P.C. 1991/1695) provides that
Treasury Board may authorize deputy heads to make ex gratia payments. As such,
the deputy minister may do so for the department of health.

summary.summary: The authority to make regulatory decisions can be assigned to the minister, other individuals such as designated inspectors, or the governor in council, depending on the legislation.

chunk_text:
Who makes regulatory decisions?

Depending on the legislation, the authority to make decisions may be
specifically assigned to the minister, to other individuals (such as
designated inspectors), or, occasionally, to the governor in council. The
following section explains how these different types of decision-making
authorities work.

summary.summary: The Minister of Health has decision-making authority in the health portfolio, with many regulatory decisions being made by the minister or on their behalf, often by governmental officials.

chunk_text:
A. The Minister of Health

1\. Decisions made by the minister or on the minister’s behalf

Decision-making authority in legislation often resides with the minister. In
the health portfolio context, this authority encompasses many possible kinds
of regulatory decisions, and on any given day, many of these decisions are
made. Accordingly, the majority of decisions are made by governmental
officials

summary.summary: Delegating regulatory decision-making has four advantages: practicality due to high volume, minimizing perceived political interference, leveraging specialized expertise, and facilitating judicial review. The responsible minister retains authority to make decisions personally if needed.

chunk_text:
This has four important advantages:

  * Given the volume of regulatory decisions required, it is not practical for a minister to personally exercise all of his or her authorities; 
  * The risk of perceived political interference in evidence-based decision-making is minimized;
  * Many regulatory decisions are highly technical in nature and require a specialized (often scientific) expertise; and
  * In the event a decision is challenged in a court of law (subject to judicial review), the person who makes the decision may need to give evidence.

At all times, where the decision-making authority in legislation resides with
the minister, the responsible minister retains the authority to personally
make those decisions

summary.summary: Regulatory officials must exercise decision-making powers with integrity, as their decisions can be scrutinized by various stakeholders, including industry, media, public, and judiciary.

chunk_text:
However, the practice of allowing officials to exercise
regulatory decision-making powers that are appropriate to their functions is
common to all regulatory departments and agencies.

Regulatory decisions can be scrutinized by industry, the media, the public,
and the judiciary. Therefore, it is essential that the minister – or
appropriately-placed officials in the health portfolio who make those
decisions on behalf of the minister – are able to demonstrate integrity in
their decision-making processes

summary.summary: Regulatory decisions should be based on objective and science-based assessments, with additional context provided for sensitive decisions.

chunk_text:
It is important to demonstrate that each
decision is the result of an objective – and, as applicable, science-based –
assessment of all the information available to the regulator.

While routine and uncontroversial regulatory decisions are made every day by
officials, if a decision is particularly sensitive in nature, additional
background information may be provided so that the minister is aware of the
context and basis for a decision.

2\

summary.summary: A minister can delegate powers, duties, and functions to officers or employees through a delegation order, as allowed by specific legislative provisions.

chunk_text:
Ministerial decision-making authority where a delegation order is required

In some specific instances, legislation may include specific provisions that
allow the minister, as head of the institution, to make an order delegating
particular powers, duties and functions to officers or employees of the
institution (or to another institution within the portfolio)

summary.summary: The Minister of Health has various decision-making authorities, including issuing notices of compliance for new drugs, ordering recalls of hazardous products, and establishing quarantine stations. These powers are granted under several acts, such as the Food and Drugs Act, Pest Control Products Act, and Canada Consumer Product Safety Act.

summary.summary: Certain acts, such as the Food and Drugs Act, Controlled Drugs and Substances Act, and Human Pathogens and Toxins Act, grant decision-making powers to individuals other than the minister, including designated inspectors with powers like entry, examination of records, and detention of substances.

chunk_text:
B. Other officials

Many acts confer decision-making powers explicitly on individuals other than
the minister.  For example, inspection powers (such as entry, examination of
records, detention of substances, etc.) can only be exercised by a designated
“inspector” in the _Food and Drugs Act_ , the _Controlled Drugs and Substances
Act_ , and the _Human Pathogens and Toxins Act_ , to name but a few

summary.summary: A quarantine officer has the authority to require health assessments for individuals suspected of carrying a communicable disease under the Quarantine Act

chunk_text:
Under the
_Quarantine Act_ , a “quarantine officer” decides whether to require health
assessments of individuals suspected of carrying a communicable disease

summary.summary: The Chief Public Health Officer makes decisions under the Quarantine Act, including granting exemptions and imposing conditions to minimize COVID-19 risk. The minister may request a briefing and discuss decisions, but does not make the decisions themselves.

chunk_text:
The
Chief Public Health Officer is responsible for making certain decisions under
the emergency orders issued under the _Quarantine Act_ , including granting
exemptions for essential workers and taking immediate public health measures
to minimize the risk of introduction or spread of COVID-19 by imposing
conditions on exempt persons.

In these instances, the minister may request a briefing in relation to the
decision-making process and discuss the decision with officials, but may not
make, nor is directly involved in, the decision itself.

summary.summary: The Patented Medicine Prices Review Board (PMPRB) is an independent, quasi-judicial body that operates under the Patent Act to regulate drug prices, determining if prices are excessive and ordering reductions or offsets if necessary.

chunk_text:
C. Independent Tribunals

Some statutes create tribunals that operate independently of a minister. One
such example in the health portfolio is the Patented Medicine Prices Review
Board (PMPRB). The PMPRB is an independent, quasi-judicial body established
under the _Patent Act_. The board determines whether the patented drug price
set by the manufacturer is excessive and, if so, the board can order price
reductions and/or the offset of excess revenues

summary.summary: The board has authority to issue non-binding guidelines after consulting with the Minister of Health and other stakeholders, and although it operates independently, the Minister of Health has defined roles in relation to the board as per the Patent Act

chunk_text:
Further, the board has the
authority to issue non-binding guidelines regarding the administration of the
board. However, before issuing any such guidelines, the board is required to
consult with the Minister of Health, as well as other stakeholders.

Although the PMPRB carries out its mandate at arms-length from the Minister of
Health and is independent of Health Canada, the _Patent Act_ sets out several
roles for the Minister of Health in relation to the PMPRB

summary.summary: The task involves recommending regulations to the governor and entering agreements with provinces to disburse collected funds.

chunk_text:
This includes
recommending new/amending regulations to the governor in council in relation
to the PMPRB regime, and entering into agreements with any province to
disburse funds collected by the PMPRB.

summary.summary: The governor in council (cabinet) can be granted decision-making power by legislation, such as making emergency orders under the Quarantine Act to control entry into Canada.

chunk_text:
D. Governor in council (cabinet)

Legislation can expressly provide that the governor in council will exercise
the decision-making power. An example of this is in the health portfolio is
the emergency orders that can be made by the governor in council under the
_Quarantine Act_ , which prohibit or impose conditions on persons entering
Canada

summary.summary: Travelers from a country with a communicable disease outbreak may be restricted from entering to prevent the introduction or spread of the disease if no other alternatives are available

chunk_text:
This can be done, for example, if they are coming from a country that
has an outbreak of a communicable disease that could pose a threat to
Canadians and no reasonable alternatives to prevent the introduction or spread
of the disease are available
challenges_keywords: introduction or spread of the disease

summary.summary: The governor in council has authority to create prohibitions and impose quarantine to prevent COVID-19 spread, and also has power under the Pest Control Products Act to cancel or amend registration of pest control products to implement international agreements

chunk_text:
Since February 2020, the governor in council
has exercised this authority to create prohibitions on entry into Canada and
to impose mandatory isolation and quarantine on travelers to prevent the
introduction and spread of COVID-19.

Another example is under the _Pest Control Products Act_ , where the governor
in council may make an order cancelling or amending the registration of a pest
control product if considered necessary to implement an international
agreement

summary.summary: The minister and departmental officials are not allowed to make certain decisions on behalf of the cabinet.

chunk_text:
Neither the minister nor departmental officials may make these
types of decisions on cabinet’s behalf.
