chunk_text: Pan-Canadian health organizations

summary.summary: The Government of Canada created pan-Canadian health organizations (PCHOs) over 30 years to address health care system needs and issues.

chunk_text:
Overview

At different points over more than thirty years, the Government of Canada
created pan-Canadian health organizations (PCHOs) to address specific health
care system needs and issues

summary.summary: There are 8 Pan-Canadian Health Organizations (PCHOs) that were created to address priorities in the Canadian healthcare system in a more targeted and flexible way than the federal government or individual provinces/territories can on their own.

chunk_text:
There are now eight such organizations.

PCHOs were created to address priorities in the Canadian health care system,
recognizing their potential to tackle issues in a more targeted, pan-Canadian
and flexible way than the federal government - or any one PT - can do on its
own or at intergovernmental tables, with diverse mandates and activities

summary.summary: Canadian health organizations, such as the CDA, Canada Health Infoway, CIHI, Canadian Partnership Against Cancer, and Mental Health Commission of Canada, are working together to improve healthcare through reimbursement reviews, virtual care, health system performance reporting, and developing national strategies for pressing health issues like cancer control and mental health.

chunk_text:
For
example, Canada’s Drug Agency (CDA)’s  reimbursement review program assesses
the cost-effectiveness of drugs; Canada Health Infoway has directly supported
provinces and territories (PTs) in the implementation of their virtual care
and digital health needs; the Canadian Institute for Health Information (CIHI)
reports on health system performance; and the Canadian Partnership Against
Cancer and the Mental Health Commission of Canada have developed national
strategies on pressing health issues (cancer control and mental health
respectively)

summary.summary: Most PCHOs were established through federal investment, but some were created in partnership with provincial/territorial governments. The federal government is the primary funder of PCHOs, accounting for 60-100% of their budgets.

chunk_text:
While most PCHOs were established exclusively through federal
investment, two (CDA and CIHI) were created in partnership with
provincial/territorial governments. The recently created Health Workforce
Canada was created to improve the collection and sharing of health workforce
data and share practical solutions and innovative practices.

The federal government remains the majority funder of all PCHOs accounting for
about 60-100% of total individual PCHO budgets

summary.summary: Provincial and territorial governments provide financial support to organizations such as CIHI and CDA, with cost-sharing on certain projects with Infoway. Each organization has a board of directors that includes federal government representation.

chunk_text:
Based on longstanding
agreements, PTs provide financial support to CIHI (approximately 20% of its
budget) and CDA (approximately 15% of its budget), while Infoway cost-shares
with PTs on some of the projects it funds.

As not-for-profit corporations, each PCHO is governed by a board of directors
on which the federal government generally holds one seat, some voting and some
as observers (and in a few cases also designates the board chair)

summary.summary: A senior Health Canada public servant serves as the federal representative on PCHO boards, which are operationally independent but accountable to the Government of Canada for federal investments and objectives.

chunk_text:
A senior
public servant from Health Canada typically serves as the federal
representative and PTs generally have public servant representation on PCHO
boards. Although PCHOs are operationally independent, they are accountable to
their majority funder - the Government of Canada – for federal investments and
related objectives, and so they have a vested interest in developing products
and services that respond to the priorities of the federal government and
their primary partners, the PTs.

summary.mandate: collecting, analyzing and reporting health data

chunk_text:
Mandate and core activities

**The Canadian Institute for Health Information (CIHI)** is the main national
body charged with collecting, analyzing and reporting health data (e.g., wait
times, quality of care and outcomes, health expenditures, allocation of health
professionals), including collaborating with PTs, StatsCan, and data partners
to develop and use comparable indicators on priority topics

keywords: The Canadian Institute for Health Information (CIHI)

summary.summary: CIHI data supports health system improvements and informs policy decisions in Canada

chunk_text:
CIHI data and
information supports health system improvements and is used by Canadian
governments, policy-makers and health system managers in making health policy
decisions and in supporting effective health system management

summary.summary: The Canadian Institute for Health Information (CIHI) relies on patient data for health information collection, while Canada's Drug Agency (CDA) provides decision-makers with evidence and advice on the effectiveness and efficiency of health technologies.

chunk_text:
CIHI relies
heavily on PTs for collection of health data.

**Canada’s Drug Agency (CDA)** provides decision-makers with evidence and
advice to help provincial/territorial health ministries and federal-
provincial/territorial (FPT) drug plans make informed decisions about the
effectiveness and efficiency of drugs, medical devices and other health
technologies

summary.summary: Expert committees provide non-binding recommendations for new drug reimbursement, while Canada Health Infoway accelerates digital health technology development and adoption to improve health outcomes.

chunk_text:
The expert committees from the reimbursement review program make
non-binding recommendations to public drug plans that support formulary
listing and reimbursement conditions decisions for new drugs.

**Canada Health Infoway (Infoway)** works with PTs, health care providers and
other partners to accelerate the development and adoption of digital health
technologies, drive health innovation, and improve health outcomes

summary.summary: Infoway is working on a pan-Canadian interoperability roadmap to support secure health data exchange.Meanwhile, Healthcare Excellence Canada is an amalgam of the Canadian Patient Safety Institute and the Canadian Foundation for Healthcare Improvement.

chunk_text:
Infoway is
currently focused on leading the development of a pan-Canadian
interoperability roadmap for supporting the secure access and exchange of
health data between digital solutions, supporting the adoption of standardized
digital health solutions, supporting the adoption of standardized digital
health tools with PTs, and an electronic proscribing system.

**Healthcare Excellence Canada** is the amalgamated organization of the
Canadian Patient Safety Institute and the Canadian Foundation for Healthcare
Improvement

summary.summary: The organization works with patients and partners to share innovations and best practices, aiming to improve patient safety and healthcare quality, and provided support to long-term care homes during the pandemic through its 'LTC+' program.

chunk_text:
It works with patients and other partners to share proven
innovations and best practices that lead to lasting improvements in patient
safety and healthcare quality (over the pandemic, its ‘LTC+’ program provided
seed funding and programming support to long-term care and retirement homes to
strengthen their pandemic preparedness and response)

focus_areas: care closer to home and community with safe transitions
care of older adults with health and social needs
pandemic recovery and health system resilience

chunk_text:
Its current focus areas
include: care closer to home and community with safe transitions; care of
older adults with health and social needs; pandemic recovery and health system
resilience.

**Health Workforce Canada** is the recently established centre of excellence
to improve health workforce data, planning and knowledge translation to
action

summary.summary: The establishment is a response to the Canadian government's 2023 budget commitments to improve health workforce data and address health workforce challenges.

chunk_text:
Its establishment responds to the Government of Canada’s budget 2023
commitments to support improvements to health workforce data as well as
federal/provincial/territorial health ministers’ commitment to take concrete
actions to address health workforce challenges

summary.summary: Two Canadian organizations, HWC and CPAC, are working to improve healthcare through data collection and cancer control strategies. HWC focuses on health workforce planning, while CPAC aims to reduce the burden of cancer through coordinated system-level change.

chunk_text:
As an independent, not-for-
profit organization, HWC is working to convene and collaborate with health
sector partners, including the Canadian Institute for Health Information, to
improve the timely development, collection and sharing of health workforce
data and advance the use of this data to support evidence-based workforce
planning.

**The Canadian Partnership Against Cancer (CPAC)** provides national
leadership to mobilize partners, including governments and cancer experts, to
reduce the burden of cancer through coordinated, system-level change through
the implementation of the Canadian strategy for cancer control (the strategy).
The strategy is a framework for Canadian cancer control that reflects the
views of cancer stakeholders, including all levels of government

summary.summary: The text discusses two main topics: cancer control continuum, which includes prevention, screening, treatment, and recovery, and the Mental Health Commission of Canada, which aims to improve the mental health system and reduce stigma associated with mental health issues.

chunk_text:
It touches
upon the full cancer control continuum from prevention, screening and early
detection to treatment, standards and cancer guidelines through recovery and
palliative care.

**The Mental Health Commission of Canada (MHCC)** acts as a catalyst for
improving the mental health system and changing the attitudes and behaviours
of Canadians around mental health issues (for example, by reducing the stigma
associated with mental health illness and treatment)

summary.summary: The Canadian Centre on Substance Use and Addiction (CCSA) focuses on four priority areas and works to exchange knowledge, mobilize research, promote awareness, and reduce harm from substance use through effective programs and stakeholder engagement.

chunk_text:
Its work focuses on four
priority areas: population-based initiatives, suicide prevention, the
integration of mental health and substance use, and engagement with Canadians.

**The Canadian Centre on Substance Use and Addiction (CCSA)** facilitates
knowledge exchange and mobilizes research and expertise in the substance use
field, promotes increased awareness among Canadians and health system
stakeholders about substance use and addiction, convenes stakeholders across
sectors (including those with lived and living experience) to reduce the harms
of substance use, and promotes the use of programs shown to be effective in
combating problematic substance use
policies_and_priorities_keywords: integration of mental health and substance use
program_and_operations_keywords: integration of mental health and substance use

keywords: The Canadian Centre on Substance Use and Addiction (CCSA)

summary.summary: CCSA is a unique PCHO established through federal legislation

chunk_text:
CCSA is the only PCHO created by federal
legislation.

summary.summary: Ministers of Health have no direct involvement in day-to-day activities of PCHOs, with funding administration delegated to Health Canada officials

chunk_text:
Ministerial role and engagement

As PCHOs are operationally independent, the Minister of Health, the Minister
of Mental Health and Addictions, and the Associate Minister of Health have no
direct involvement in their day-to-day activities. The administration of
contribution funding to each organization is delegated to Health Canada
officials

keywords: Minister of Mental Health and Addictions
Minister of Mental Health and Addictions

summary.summary: The Minister of Health has oversight of federal investments and funding for various organizations, and is responsible for nominating representatives to certain boards, including CPAC, MHCC, and CCSA, with the deputy minister handling most federal board appointments.

chunk_text:
The Minister of Health has ultimate oversight of federal
investments in these organizations, including the use of federal funding to
advance priorities and requests through cabinet for new funding to support
emerging federal or FPT priorities.

Most federal board appointments are the prerogative of the deputy minister.
However, the minister is charged with nominating a federal representative to
the CPAC board of directors; the chair and one additional federal
representative to the MHCC board of directors; and recommends governor in
council appointments for the chair and up to four other representatives to the
CCSA board of directors

summary.summary: The minister can expect PCHOs to seek direct engagement on matters relevant to their organizations due to their close relationship with the department.

chunk_text:
Given the close relationship between the department
and the organizations, the minister can also expect PCHOs to seek direct
engagement from time to time on matters of relevance to their respective
organizations.

summary.summary: Primary Contact Health Organizations (PCHOs) play a crucial role in Canada's decentralized health system, facilitating the advancement of federal interests at a pan-Canadian level, and are often more accepted by provinces and territories than direct federal intervention.

chunk_text:
Role in the health system

PCHOs play an important role in the health system. In Canada’s decentralized
system, they can be helpful in advancing federal interests in areas of
provincial/territorial responsibility, on a pan-Canadian scale. PTs are often
more receptive to PCHO engagement than to direct federal government
intervention

summary.summary: The shared governance model of Primary and Community Health Organizations (PCHOs) contributes to their effectiveness. An external review in 2018 recommended structural changes to meet Canada's future health system needs.

chunk_text:
This is attributable in part to the shared governance model
adopted by most PCHOs.

In 2018, an external review of the role of the PCHOs was conducted and
produced a series of recommendations, including structural changes. In it,
Drs. PG Forest and Danielle Martin made clear that while these organizations
have made significant contributions over the years, the suite of PCHOs needs
to be reconfigured and/or re-mandated to meet the needs of Canada's health
systems in the future

summary.summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has increased the need for organizations to be responsive to federal needs, and in 2021, the CFHI and CPSI amalgamated, while Health Canada encourages collaboration between CCSA and MHCC on mental health and substance use policy and practice.

chunk_text:
Since the issuance of the report, the COVID-19 pandemic
has further reinforced the need for organizations to be focused and responsive
to federal and PT needs and objectives.

The amalgamation of CFHI and CPSI was a key structural change in 2021. Health
Canada continues to reinforce opportunities for CCSA and MHCC to collaborate
on initiatives that support an integrated/systems approach to MHSU&A policy
and practice

summary.summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has had significant impacts on mental health and substance use, amplifying existing concerns. Health Canada is implementing process improvements to enhance the contribution of Primary Care Health Organizations (PCHOs) to health system improvement priorities at the federal and provincial/territorial levels.

chunk_text:
The mental health and substance use impacts of the COVID-19
pandemic have been profound, amplifying the significant and expanding needs of
people with mental health or substance use concerns, and the close
interrelationship between these two areas.

In addition, Health Canada has been undertaking several recommended process
improvements aimed at ensuring the PCHOs, individually and collectively,
contribute in a more impactful manner to federal and provincial/territorial
priorities for health system improvement

summary.summary: Health Canada and Public Health Chief Officers (PCHOs) are collaborating to improve funding administration, promote cultural safety, and support Canadian health systems during the pandemic through coordinated responses and guidance.

chunk_text:
For example, Health Canada worked to
clarify and improve the efficiency of funding administration and PCHOs are
working together to drive progress on cultural safety and Indigenous
reconciliation.

To better support Canadian health systems in their response to the pandemic, a
PCHO chief executive officer table has also met biweekly to provide a
coordinated response to urgent priorities with guidance from Health Canada

summary.summary: Health Canada is working with Provincial and Territorial governments (PTs) to provide guidance and support for specific priorities, including virtual care during COVID-19, in collaboration with Canada Health Infoway.

chunk_text:
In
addition, Health Canada has been working closely with PTs to ensure that
individual PCHOs have the guidance and direction needed to better support work
on specific priorities, such as Canada Health Infoway’s work during COVID-19
to support PTs on virtual care.

summary.summary: The health portfolio collaborates with various stakeholders, including provinces, Indigenous partners, health organizations, non-governmental organizations, professional associations, charities, international organizations, industry, research community, federal departments, foreign regulators, and the public.

chunk_text:
Other key players and stakeholders

The health portfolio works with a variety of key players in health, including
provinces and territories, Indigenous partners, federally funded arm’s-length
health organizations, non-governmental organizations, professional
associations, charities, international organizations, industry, the research
community, other federal departments and agencies, foreign regulators and
people living in Canada

summary.summary: The work involves collaboration on research, surveillance, public consultation, policy development, information sharing, and engagement with people who have personal experience to improve the health system.

chunk_text:
This work includes partnering on research,
surveillance, public consultation, collaborative policy and program
development, sharing information to support health system improvement, best
practice/knowledge sharing and engagement with people with lived and living
experience.

summary.summary: No text was provided to summarize. The section 'IV. Annexes' appears to be a title or heading, but there is no content to extract or summarize.

chunk_text: IV. Annexes

summary.summary: The Minister of Health mandate letter, dated December 16, 2021, acknowledges the challenges Canadians have faced during the pandemic and expresses appreciation for their resilience and values of compassion, courage, and determination.

chunk_text:
Minister of Health mandate letter

December 16, 2021

Dear Minister Duclos:

Thank you for agreeing to serve Canadians as Minister of Health.

From the beginning of this pandemic, Canadians have faced a once-in-a-century
challenge. And through it all, from coast to coast to coast, people have met
the moment. When it mattered most, Canadians adapted, helped one another, and
stayed true to our values of compassion, courage and determination. That is
what has defined our path through this pandemic so far

summary.summary: The Canadian government is committed to delivering on the democratic choice made by Canadians, finishing the fight against COVID-19, supporting the middle class, and taking bold action to build a healthier and more resilient future.

chunk_text:
And that is what will
pave our way forward.

During a difficult time, Canadians made a democratic choice. They entrusted us
to finish the fight against COVID-19 and support the recovery of a strong
middle class. At the same time, they also gave us clear direction: to take
bold, concrete action to build a healthier, more resilient future. That is
what Canadians have asked us to do and it is exactly what our Government is
ready to deliver

keywords: support the recovery of a strong middle class
recovery of a strong middle class

summary.summary: The goal is to create a better future through teamwork, community involvement, and informed decision-making based on scientific evidence.

chunk_text:
We will work to build that brighter future through continued
collaboration, engagement, and the use of science and evidence-based decision-
making

summary.summary: The government is committed to working with various stakeholders to build a stronger, more resilient, and inclusive country, with a focus on taking urgent climate action to address the clear demands of Canadians and scientific evidence.

chunk_text:
With an unwavering focus on delivering results, we will work
constructively with Parliamentarians and maintain our strong partnerships with
provincial, territorial and municipal governments and Indigenous partners.
This decade has had an incredibly difficult start, but this is the moment to
rebuild a more resilient, inclusive and stronger country for everyone.

The science is clear. Canadians have been clear. We must not only continue
taking real climate action, we must also move faster and go further

summary.summary: Climate change is a significant threat to Canadians, and addressing it will require a collaborative effort to build a cleaner and greener future.

chunk_text:
As
Canadians are increasingly experiencing across the country, climate change is
an existential threat. Building a cleaner, greener future will require a
sustained and collaborative effort from all of us

summary.summary: The Minister is expected to support reducing emissions and addressing climate-related challenges, and to accelerate reconciliation with First Nations, Inuit, and Métis Peoples, following the discovery of unmarked graves near former residential schools.

chunk_text:
As Minister, I expect you
to seek opportunities within your portfolio to support our whole-of-government
effort to reduce emissions, create clean jobs and address the climate-related
challenges communities are already facing.

This year, Canadians were horrified by the discovery of unmarked graves and
burial sites near former residential schools. These discoveries underscore
that we must move faster on the path of reconciliation with First Nations,
Inuit and Métis Peoples

summary.summary: The government acknowledges that reconciliation requires truth and will continue to invest in it

chunk_text:
We know that reconciliation cannot come without truth
and our Government will continue to invest in that truth

summary.summary: Ministers are directed to implement the UN Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples and work with Indigenous Peoples to address systemic inequities and disparities in society and institutions.

chunk_text:
As Ministers, each
of us has a duty to further this work, both collectively and as individuals.
Consequently, I am directing every Minister to implement the United Nations
Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples and to work in partnership
with Indigenous Peoples to advance their rights.

We must continue to address the profound systemic inequities and disparities
that remain present in the core fabric of our society, including our core
institutions
policies_and_priorities_keywords: United Nations Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples
program_and_operations_keywords: United Nations Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples

keywords: United Nations Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples

summary.summary: The Minister expects collaboration with various communities and incorporation of diverse Canadian views into government priorities and work.

chunk_text:
To this effect, it is essential that Canadians in every region
of the country see themselves reflected in our Government’s priorities and our
work. As Minister, I expect you to include and collaborate with various
communities, and actively seek out and incorporate in your work, the diverse
views of Canadians

summary.summary: The text emphasizes the importance of considering diverse groups, including women, Indigenous Peoples, and LGBTQ2 Canadians, in public policy development using an intersectional lens, and also mentions the role of journalism in providing accurate news to Canadians.

chunk_text:
This includes women, Indigenous Peoples, Black and
racialized Canadians, newcomers, faith-based communities, persons with
disabilities, LGBTQ2 Canadians, and, in both official languages.

Across our work, we remain committed to ensuring that public policies are
informed and developed through an intersectional lens, including applying
frameworks such as Gender-based Analysis Plus (GBA Plus) and the quality of
life indicators in decision-making.

Canadians continue to rely on journalists and journalism for accurate and
timely news

summary.summary: Maintain professional relationships with journalists to keep Canadians informed and safe, and adapt government services based on pandemic lessons to better serve Canadians.

chunk_text:
I expect you to maintain professional and respectful
relationships with journalists to ensure that Canadians are well informed and
have the information they need to keep themselves and their families safe.

Throughout the course of the pandemic, Canadians and their governments have
adapted to new realities. Governments must draw on lessons learned from the
pandemic to further adapt and develop more agile and effective ways to serve
Canadians

summary.summary: The government expects ministers to update practices to meet current and future challenges. Success requires collaboration across parties in the House of Commons and Senate to achieve goals for Canadians, with ministers expected to maintain constructive relationships with Opposition Critics and coordinate legislation with the Leader of the Government in the House of Commons.

chunk_text:
To this end, I expect all Ministers to evaluate ways we can update
our practices to ensure our Government continues to meet the challenges of
today and tomorrow.

The success of this Parliament will require Parliamentarians, both in the
House of Commons and the Senate, to work together across all parties to get
big things done for Canadians. I expect you to maintain constructive
relationships with your Opposition Critics and coordinate any legislation with
the Leader of the Government in the House of Commons

keywords: Leader of the Government in the House of Commons

summary.summary: The Minister is accountable to Parliament for their performance and leadership, and must adhere to the principles and standards outlined in the Open and Accountable Government document, which lays out the expectations for Ministry members.

chunk_text:
As Minister, you are
accountable to Parliament both individually, for your style of leadership and
the performance of your responsibilities, and collectively, in support of our
Ministry and decisions taken by cabinet. Open and Accountable Government sets
out these core principles and the standards of conduct expected of you and
your office. I expect you to familiarize yourself with this document, which
outlines my expectations for each member of the Ministry.

Our platform lays out an ambitious agenda

summary.summary: The Minister of Health's priority is to finish the fight against COVID-19 and strengthen the public health care system, with increased investments in primary and virtual care, and mental health services, to ensure all Canadians have access to necessary care.

chunk_text:
While finishing the fight against
the pandemic must remain our central focus, we must continue building a strong
middle class and work toward a better future where everyone has a real and
fair chance at success and no one is left behind.

As Minister of Health, your immediate priority is to help finish the fight
against COVID-19, working in close cooperation with provinces and territories.
As we emerge from this pandemic, I expect you to work in partnership with
provinces and territories to strengthen our universal public health care
system and public health supports, backed by an early increase of investments
in primary and virtual care and mental health services so all Canadians can
get the care they need no matter where they live

summary.summary: The Canadian government aims to collaborate with provinces and territories to improve the primary care system, long-term care, and continue the fight against COVID-19. Key commitments include rolling out COVID-19 vaccines, ensuring sufficient domestic supply, implementing public health measures, and launching a COVID-19 Proof of Vaccination Fund. The government will also work to protect the health and safety of Canadians through border management and support the Public Health Agency of Canada.

The Minister of Innovation, Science and Industry will work to strengthen public health by improving surveillance, securing medical supply chains, advancing biomanufacturing, and studying the long-term health impacts of COVID-19, particularly on vulnerable populations and children.

chunk_text: * Work with the Minister of Innovation, Science and Industry to continue demonstrating leadership in public health by strengthening surveillance and capacity to detect and act on public health threats, strengthening the security of medical supply chains, working with colleagues to advance the Biomanufacturing and Life Sciences Strategy, and investing in the study of the long-term health impacts of COVID-19, including the effects of long COVID on different groups, notably vulnerable populations and children

keywords: Minister of Innovation, Science and Industry

summary.summary: The Canadian government plans to strengthen its public health system by increasing funding to provinces and territories, supporting healthcare workers, and advancing a patient-centric strategy using data and digital systems. Key initiatives include investing in access to critical services, hiring new healthcare professionals, expanding virtual care, improving rural healthcare, and modernizing the Canada Health Act. A world-class health data system is also being developed in consultation with provinces and territories.
key_initiatives: investing in access to critical services
developing a world-class health data system

keywords: Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance

summary.summary: Establish a permanent Canada Mental Health Transfer to expand high-quality, accessible, and free mental health services, with support from government officials.

chunk_text: * Work with the Minister of Mental Health and Addictions and Associate Minister of Health and with the support of the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance to establish a permanent, ongoing Canada Mental Health Transfer, to help expand the delivery of high-quality, accessible and free mental health services, including for prevention and treatment

keywords: Minister of Mental Health and Addictions

key_partners_keywords: Minister of Mental Health and Addictions

summary.summary: The Minister of Seniors is working to improve long-term care homes by negotiating agreements with provinces and territories to enhance quality, availability, and infection control, with goals of developing national standards and a Safe Long-Term Care Act.

chunk_text: * With the support of the Minister of Seniors, negotiate agreements with provinces and territories to support efforts to improve the quality and availability of long-term care homes and beds. This includes working with provinces and territories to improve infection prevention and control measures, identify shared principles, and develop national standards and a Safe Long-Term Care Act to ensure seniors get the care they deserve

summary.summary: The Canadian government aims to ensure all Canadians have access to sexual and reproductive health services, regardless of location, by reinforcing the Canada Health Act, developing a health rights portal, supporting in vitro fertilization cost coverage, and funding youth-led organizations.

chunk_text: * With the support of the Minister for Women and Gender Equality and Youth, work to ensure that all Canadians have access to the sexual and reproductive health services they need, no matter where they live, by reinforcing compliance under the Canada Health Act, developing a sexual and reproductive health rights information portal, supporting the establishment of mechanisms to help families cover the costs of in vitro fertilization, and supporting youth-led grassroots organizations that respond to the unique sexual and reproductive health needs of young people

summary.summary: The goal is to develop a plan with the Minister of Innovation, Science and Industry to modernize Canada's federal research funding ecosystem, modeled after DARPA, focusing on maximizing research excellence and innovation impact, particularly among federal research granting agencies and the Canada Foundation for Innovation.

chunk_text: * In moving forward with a uniquely Canadian approach modeled on the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency (DARPA), work with the Minister of Innovation, Science and Industry to develop a plan to modernize the federal research funding ecosystem to maximize the impact of investments in both research excellence and downstream innovation, with a particular focus on the relationships among the federal research granting agencies and the Canada Foundation for Innovation

keywords: Minister of Innovation, Science and Industry

summary.summary: Two main actions are outlined: (1) integrating science and evidence into pandemic response with the Chief Science Advisor's support, and (2) collaborating with the Minister of Foreign Affairs and Minister of International Development to ensure global access to COVID-19 health interventions, including vaccines and therapeutics.

chunk_text:
* With the support of the Chief Science Advisor, continue to ensure science and evidence are integrated into our pandemic response. 
  * With the support of the Minister of Foreign Affairs, work with the Minister of International Development to continue to reinforce international efforts to ensure that people around the world have access to health interventions to fight COVID-19, including vaccines, therapeutics and strengthened health systems

summary.summary: The goals include combating antimicrobial resistance and working towards national universal pharmacare and a national strategy for high-cost drugs for rare diseases.

chunk_text:
* Work with partners to take increased and expedited action to monitor, prevent and mitigate the serious and growing threat of antimicrobial resistance and preserve the effectiveness of the antimicrobials Canadians rely upon every day. 
  * Continue engaging with willing provinces and territories towards national universal pharmacare, while proceeding with a national strategy on high-cost drugs for rare diseases and advancing the establishment of the Canada Drug Agency

summary.summary: The plan aims to protect Canadians from harmful chemicals by strengthening the Canadian Environmental Protection Act, introducing mandatory labeling, ending animal testing, increasing product compliance testing, and protecting against toxic flame retardants.

chunk_text: * To protect Canadians from harmful chemicals, strengthen the Canadian Environmental Protection Act, introduce mandatory labelling of chemicals in consumer products, introduce legislation to end testing on animals, increase testing of products for compliance with Canadian standards, and implement an action plan to protect Canadians, including firefighters, from exposure to toxic flame retardants found in household products

  * Recognizing that a healthy population is key to reducing vulnerability to health events, promote healthy eating by advancing the Healthy Eating Strategy

summary.summary: The text requests a Minister to support colleagues, leverage department expertise and personal experiences to achieve results for Canadians, and submit a proposed approach for implementing mandate commitments with priorities for early implementation.

chunk_text:
I
expect you to support your colleagues in delivering their commitments,
leveraging the expertise of your department and your own lived experiences.

To best achieve results for Canadians, Ministers must be rigorous and
coordinated in our approach to implementation. I would therefore ask that you
return to me with a proposed approach for the delivery of your mandate
commitments, including priorities for early implementation

summary.summary: The speaker will require public progress reports on commitments, emphasizing the importance of government adaptability, especially during times of change like the pandemic.

chunk_text:
Furthermore, to
ensure we are accountable for our work, I will be asking you to publicly
report to me, and all Canadians, on your progress toward these commitments on
a regular basis.

As we have been reminded throughout the pandemic, adapting to change is not
only something government should do, it is something government must do

summary.summary: The expectation is to consider new ideas and issues, work with the Deputy Minister to assess priorities, and focus on building a better future for Canadians.

chunk_text:
As
you work to fulfil our commitments, I expect you to actively consider new
ideas and issues as they emerge, whether through public engagement, your work
with Parliamentarians or advice from the public service. I also expect you to
work with your Deputy Minister to assess priorities on a continual basis as we
build a better future for all Canadians

summary.summary: You are responsible for overseeing your department and ensuring its effective operation, while also upholding principles of equity, diversity, and inclusion when staffing and recruiting for leadership positions.

chunk_text:
In addition to achieving results, you
are responsible for overseeing the work of your department and ensuring the
effective operation of your portfolio.

As you staff your office and implement outreach and recruitment strategies for
federally appointed leadership positions and boards, I ask that you uphold the
principles of equity, diversity and inclusion. This helps ensure that federal
workplaces are dynamic and reflective of the Canadians we serve

keywords: federally appointed leadership positions and boards

summary.summary: Ensure a safe work environment and uphold Canadian expectations of hard work, honesty, and commitment to their interests

chunk_text:
You will also
ensure your Minister’s office and portfolio are reflective of our commitment
to healthy and safe workplaces.

Canadians expect us to work hard, speak truthfully and be committed to
advancing their interests and aspirations

summary.summary: The Prime Minister of Canada, Justin Trudeau, expects ministers to acknowledge and learn from their mistakes, and offers his support and that of the Deputy Prime Minister to help them fulfill their responsibilities.

chunk_text:
When we make mistakes – as we all
will – Canadians expect us to acknowledge them, and most importantly, to learn
from them.

I know I can count on you to fulfill the important responsibilities entrusted
in you, and to turn to me, and the Deputy Prime Minister, early and often to
support you in your role as Minister.

Sincerely,  
Rt. Hon. Justin Trudeau, P.C., M.P.  
Prime Minister of Canada

section_title: Minister of Mental Health and Addictions mandate letter

summary.summary: The Minister of Mental Health and Addictions received a mandate letter on December 16, 2021, thanking them for serving Canadians and acknowledging the pandemic's challenges.

chunk_text:
Minister of Mental Health and Addictions mandate letter

December 16, 2021

Dear Minister Bennett:

Thank you for agreeing to serve Canadians as Minister of Mental Health and
Addictions and Associate Minister of Health.

From the beginning of this pandemic, Canadians have faced a once-in-a-century
challenge. And through it all, from coast to coast to coast, people have met
the moment

keywords: Minister of Mental Health and Addictions
Minister of Mental Health and Addictions

section_title: Minister of Mental Health and Addictions mandate letter

summary.summary: The text describes how Canadians have coped with the pandemic by adapting, helping each other, and staying true to their values. It also mentions that Canadians have made a democratic choice to support the current government in finishing the fight against COVID-19 and recovering the economy, particularly for the middle class.

chunk_text:
When it mattered most, Canadians adapted, helped one another, and
stayed true to our values of compassion, courage and determination. That is
what has defined our path through this pandemic so far. And that is what will
pave our way forward.

During a difficult time, Canadians made a democratic choice. They entrusted us
to finish the fight against COVID-19 and support the recovery of a strong
middle class

keywords: support the recovery of a strong middle class
support the recovery of a strong middle class

section_title: Minister of Mental Health and Addictions mandate letter

summary.summary: The Canadian government will take bold action to build a healthier future, working collaboratively and using science and evidence-based decision-making to deliver on Canadians' requests.

chunk_text:
At the same time, they also gave us clear direction: to take
bold, concrete action to build a healthier, more resilient future. That is
what Canadians have asked us to do and it is exactly what our Government is
ready to deliver. We will work to build that brighter future through continued
collaboration, engagement, and the use of science and evidence-based decision-
making

section_title: Minister of Mental Health and Addictions mandate letter

summary.summary: The government will work with parliamentarians and partners to rebuild a stronger, more resilient, and inclusive country, with a focus on taking faster and more significant climate action.

chunk_text:
With an unwavering focus on delivering results, we will work
constructively with Parliamentarians and maintain our strong partnerships with
provincial, territorial and municipal governments and Indigenous partners.
This decade has had an incredibly difficult start, but this is the moment to
rebuild a more resilient, inclusive and stronger country for everyone.

The science is clear. Canadians have been clear. We must not only continue
taking real climate action, we must also move faster and go further

section_title: Minister of Mental Health and Addictions mandate letter

summary.summary: Climate change is a significant threat to Canadians, and a collaborative effort is needed to build a cleaner and greener future.

chunk_text:
As
Canadians are increasingly experiencing across the country, climate change is
an existential threat. Building a cleaner, greener future will require a
sustained and collaborative effort from all of us

section_title: Minister of Mental Health and Addictions mandate letter

summary.summary: A minister is expected to support reducing emissions and addressing climate-related challenges, as well as move faster on reconciliation with First Nations, Inuit, and Métis Peoples following the discovery of unmarked graves near former residential schools.

chunk_text:
As Minister, I expect you
to seek opportunities within your portfolio to support our whole-of-government
effort to reduce emissions, create clean jobs and address the climate-related
challenges communities are already facing.

This year, Canadians were horrified by the discovery of unmarked graves and
burial sites near former residential schools. These discoveries underscore
that we must move faster on the path of reconciliation with First Nations,
Inuit and Métis Peoples
challenges_keywords: reconciliation with First Nations, Inuit and Métis Peoples

section_title: Minister of Mental Health and Addictions mandate letter

summary.summary: The government believes that reconciliation requires truth and will continue to invest in discovering and acknowledging the truth.

chunk_text:
We know that reconciliation cannot come without truth
and our Government will continue to invest in that truth

section_title: Minister of Mental Health and Addictions mandate letter

summary.summary: Ministers are directed to implement the United Nations Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples and work with Indigenous Peoples to address systemic inequities and disparities in society and institutions.

chunk_text:
As Ministers, each
of us has a duty to further this work, both collectively and as individuals.
Consequently, I am directing every Minister to implement the United Nations
Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples and to work in partnership
with Indigenous Peoples to advance their rights.

We must continue to address the profound systemic inequities and disparities
that remain present in the core fabric of our society, including our core
institutions

United Nations Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples

section_title: Minister of Mental Health and Addictions mandate letter

summary.summary: The Minister is expected to collaborate with various Canadian communities, seeking and incorporating diverse views to ensure all regions feel reflected in the Government's priorities.

chunk_text:
To this effect, it is essential that Canadians in every region
of the country see themselves reflected in our Government’s priorities and our
work. As Minister, I expect you to include and collaborate with various
communities, and actively seek out and incorporate in your work, the diverse
views of Canadians

section_title: Minister of Mental Health and Addictions mandate letter

summary.summary: The text emphasizes commitment to inclusivity and diversity, considering the needs of various groups such as women, Indigenous Peoples, and marginalized communities. It also highlights the importance of intersectional approaches like Gender-based Analysis Plus (GBA Plus) in public policy development and decision-making.

chunk_text:
This includes women, Indigenous Peoples, Black and
racialized Canadians, newcomers, faith-based communities, persons with
disabilities, LGBTQ2 Canadians, and, in both official languages.

Across our work, we remain committed to ensuring that public policies are
informed and developed through an intersectional lens, including applying
frameworks such as Gender-based Analysis Plus (GBA Plus) and the quality of
life indicators in decision-making.

Canadians continue to rely on journalists and journalism for accurate and
timely news

section_title: Minister of Mental Health and Addictions mandate letter

summary.summary: The goal is to maintain professional relationships with journalists to keep Canadians informed and safe, and for governments to adapt and improve their services based on lessons learned from the pandemic.

chunk_text:
I expect you to maintain professional and respectful
relationships with journalists to ensure that Canadians are well informed and
have the information they need to keep themselves and their families safe.

Throughout the course of the pandemic, Canadians and their governments have
adapted to new realities. Governments must draw on lessons learned from the
pandemic to further adapt and develop more agile and effective ways to serve
Canadians

section_title: Minister of Mental Health and Addictions mandate letter

summary.summary: The government expects ministers to update practices to address current and future challenges. Success in the Parliament requires collaboration among parliamentarians across parties to achieve significant results for Canadians, maintaining constructive relationships with opposition critics and coordinating legislation with the Leader of the Government in the House of Commons.

chunk_text:
To this end, I expect all Ministers to evaluate ways we can update
our practices to ensure our Government continues to meet the challenges of
today and tomorrow.

The success of this Parliament will require Parliamentarians, both in the
House of Commons and the Senate, to work together across all parties to get
big things done for Canadians. I expect you to maintain constructive
relationships with your Opposition Critics and coordinate any legislation with
the Leader of the Government in the House of Commons

section_title: Minister of Mental Health and Addictions mandate letter

summary.summary: The Minister is accountable to Parliament for their leadership and performance, and is expected to follow the principles and standards outlined in the Open and Accountable Government document, which sets out the expectations for Ministry members.

chunk_text:
As Minister, you are
accountable to Parliament both individually, for your style of leadership and
the performance of your responsibilities, and collectively, in support of our
Ministry and decisions taken by cabinet. Open and Accountable Government sets
out these core principles and the standards of conduct expected of you and
your office. I expect you to familiarize yourself with this document, which
outlines my expectations for each member of the Ministry.

Our platform lays out an ambitious agenda

section_title: Minister of Mental Health and Addictions mandate letter

summary.summary: The Minister of Mental Health and Addictions and Associate Minister of Health must focus on building a healthier future, addressing health inequities, and ensuring everyone has a fair chance at success, particularly for Indigenous Peoples, Black Canadians, and vulnerable Canadians.

chunk_text:
While finishing the fight against
the pandemic must remain our central focus, we must continue building a strong
middle class and work toward a better future where everyone has a real and
fair chance at success and no one is left behind.

As Minister of Mental Health and Addictions and Associate Minister of Health,
you will work with the Minister of Health to build a healthier future, with a
particular focus on ensuring that health inequities are understood and
addressed, including for Indigenous Peoples, Black Canadians and vulnerable
Canadians

keywords: Minister of Mental Health and Addictions

section_title: Minister of Mental Health and Addictions mandate letter

summary.summary: The objective is to make mental health care an equal part of Canada's universal health care system, addressing substance use and expanding high-quality mental health services through a permanent Canada Mental Health Transfer.
key_points: Establish permanent Canada Mental Health Transfer

chunk_text:
You will work to ensure that mental health care is treated as a
full and equal part of our universal health care system, working in close
collaboration with provinces and territories, and lead a whole-of-society
approach to address problematic substance use in Canada.

To realize these objectives, I ask that you achieve results for Canadians by
delivering the following commitments.

  * Work with the Minister of Health, and with the support of the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance, to establish a permanent, ongoing Canada Mental Health Transfer to help expand the delivery of high-quality, accessible and free mental health services, including for prevention and treatment

keywords: Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance

section_title: Minister of Mental Health and Addictions mandate letter

summary.summary: The Canadian government plans to develop and implement a comprehensive mental health plan, focusing on health equity, virtual services, perinatal mental health, suicide prevention, and student mental health, including targeted support for Black and racialized students.

section_title: Minister of Mental Health and Addictions mandate letter

summary.summary: The goal is to co-develop a Mental Health and Wellness Strategy with the Minister of Indigenous Services, focusing on culturally appropriate services for First Nations, Inuit, and the Métis Nation, including addiction and trauma support, suicide prevention, and treatment centers.

chunk_text: * Support the Minister of Indigenous Services to co-develop and invest in a distinctions-based Mental Health and Wellness Strategy to meet the needs of First Nations, Inuit and the Métis Nation, including culturally appropriate wraparound services for addiction and trauma, suicide and life promotion and the building of treatment centres

section_title: Minister of Mental Health and Addictions mandate letter

summary.summary: Oversee mental health investments for disproportionately impacted groups, including healthcare workers and marginalized communities, and collaborate with ministers to ensure accessible mental health supports for children and youth recovering from the pandemic.

chunk_text:
* Oversee the implementation of our investments in mental health interventions and supports for people disproportionately impacted by COVID-19, including health care workers, front-line workers, seniors, Indigenous people, and Black and racialized Canadians. 
  * Work with the Minister of Families, Children and Social Development and Minister for Women and Gender Equality and Youth to ensure mental health supports are accessible to children and youth as they recover from the impact of the pandemic

Minister for Women and Gender Equality and Youth

section_title: Minister of Mental Health and Addictions mandate letter

summary.summary: The Canadian government aims to address substance use and tobacco control by implementing a comprehensive strategy, reducing stigma, and providing evidence-based treatment and harm reduction. Additionally, tobacco manufacturers will be required to cover the costs of federal public health investments in tobacco control.

chunk_text:
* Advance a comprehensive strategy to address problematic substance use in Canada, supporting efforts to improve public education to reduce stigma, and supporting provinces and territories and working with Indigenous communities to provide access to a full range of evidence-based treatment and harm reduction, as well as to create standards for substance use treatment programs. 
  * Require tobacco manufacturers to pay for the cost of federal public health investments in tobacco control

section_title: Minister of Mental Health and Addictions mandate letter

summary.summary: The goals are to support the advancement of Canada's National Action Plan on Post-Traumatic Stress Injuries for first responders and to ensure Canadian Armed Forces members and Veterans have access to adequate mental health resources and services.

chunk_text:
* Support the Minister of Public Safety to continue advancing Canada’s first-ever National Action Plan on Post-Traumatic Stress Injuries, including additional investment to support the health and well-being of first responders. 
  * Support the Minister of Veterans Affairs to ensure Canadian Armed Forces members and Veterans have access to adequate mental health resources, services and training programs tailored to their specific needs
